subject: Education
title: Sunday Schools: Education for the Poor
description: A 1-minute de-risking session on Sunday Schools: Education for the Poor.

hook.text: In 1780s England, children worked in factories six days a week. Sunday was the only day they could learn to read.

buildup.text: Robert Raikes started Sunday Schools in Gloucester. Within decades, 1.5 million English children attended weekly.

climax.text: Sunday Schools proved that even one day of education per week could transform lives. They paved the way for public

punchline.text: The first mass education happened on the only day kids weren't working.

quiz.question: Why were Sunday Schools created in 18th-century England?
options: Children worked six days a week and Sunday was their only free day
